children: OpenAgents
The Agents Platform
Christopher David
Founder & CEO
chris@openagents.com
Problem
There is no easy way to create and command your personal AI agents.
It's 1997 for agents
Agents today feel like the early web: clunky, unreliable, and non-standard.
Solution
A unifying platform that's a one-stop shop for deploying & managing the best AI agents.
OpenAgents builds and sells the best AI agents
We wedge with coding/dev agents, then expand across verticals.
Flagship vertical agents: coding, research, security, legal, sales, support.
Wedge: coding/dev agents where value is obvious and users already pay.
Agents are assembled from modular components sourced via the developer marketplace.
Best agents (powered by best components) are available exclusively on OpenAgents.
Segments: SMB, Enterprise, Government.

props.title: After onboarding: GitHub connected, real repo, coding

children: Hire the best agents in one place
Find, run, and pay top agents across every department.
One marketplace across coding, research, security, sales, support, and more.
Every agent has trust scores, verification, and performance history.
Users pick an agent and press run - no prompt assembly or tool wiring required.
It's 1997 for agents
The infrastructure for reliable, composable, purchasable agents is still missing.

props.code:
| Category | Web in 1997 | Agents in 2025 | OpenAgents in 2028 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| UX | Blinky GIFs, messy pages | Janky UIs, token logs | Production-grade, streaming results |
| Core tech | Static brochure sites | Single-turn tools | Multi-agent orchestration + routing |
| Reliability | Frequent errors | Loops, silent failures | Verified outputs + fault tolerance |
| DevEx | Hand-coded HTML | Hand-rolled prompts | Open protocols + audit trails |
| Enterprise | "We have a website" | "We have a demo" | Policy + compliance + histories |

children: Vertical agent silos are brittle and expensive
The world does not need 1,000 siloed stacks. It needs one marketplace.
The shift: from one-off agents to reusable components
The marketplace with the strongest developer ecosystem will own the best agents.
Open protocols turn vertical agents into reusable building blocks (tools, skills, workflows).
Millions of permissionless components enable many more agents on top.
Enterprises need safe routing across agents/providers with budgets + policy + verification.
Thesis: best dev ecosystem -> best components -> best agents -> more users -> more revenue -> more devs.
OpenAgents Marketplace + Dev Ecosystem
One destination for demand, one ecosystem for supply.
Marketplace
One place to hire high-performing agents with trust scores, verification, and reputation.
Usage-based pricing; payments can clear instantly over Lightning.
Results backed by replayable execution histories.
Dev ecosystem
Developers publish components (tools, skills, workflows, evaluators).
OpenAgents composes components into flagship agents and shares revenue.
Open protocols (Nostr/NIP-90, Lightning) provide global supply; the marketplace is the destination.
Loop: best dev ecosystem -> best components -> best agents -> more users -> more revenue -> more devs.
The Agent Dashboard: Factorio for Agents
How teams operate fleets of agents, not just chat with them.
Agent orchestration: visual node graph for multi-agent workflows.
Real-time metrics: earnings, token usage, throughput, reliability.
Marketplace discovery: find and deploy agents instantly.
Reputation + policy: trust scores, provider performance, enterprise rules.
Under the hood: an agent component marketplace
Flagship agents are built from modular components with measured performance.
Flagship agents: Code Fixer, Security Scan, Research Pro, Legal Review, Sales Intel, Support Bot.
Components: tools, skills, workflows, evaluators, test harnesses.
Developers earn via revenue share; performance data makes the best rise to the top.
Because we own both the component layer and the marketplace, the highest-performing agents stay exclusive to OpenAgents.

props.code:
Core primitives (Agentic OS)
  - Identity: threshold keys (FROST/FROSTR)
  - Transport: Nostr (open protocols + relays)
  - Payments: Lightning (+ Spark L2)
  - Budgets: autonomy levels + spend caps
  - Transparency: receipts + replayable histories

children: Why we win: the marketplace flywheel
The best agents win because the best developers build here.
1. Best developer ecosystem
2. Better components
3. Best-performing agents
4. More users and jobs
5. More revenue for developers
6. More and better developers join
Performance data and reputation decide which agents deliver; Lightning makes monetization instant.
How a job flows through OpenAgents
Policy + verification + reputation updates at the OpenAgents boundary.
Market
We capture value as the place agents are bought and sold, and the rails that power them.
TAM: $1.2T (global IT services + software spend reshaped by agents).
SAM: $50B (agent infra, orchestration, governance).
SOM: $500M (developer-first agent infra by Year 5).

props.code:
Market growth drivers
  - Agent proliferation (100s -> millions)
  - Multi-agent architectures become standard
  - Enterprise compliance requirements
  - Lightning micropayments enable new economics

children: Business model: take rate + SaaS + compute + payments
Multi-revenue platform with high-margin marketplace economics.

props.code:
| Revenue stream | Model | Target margin |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Marketplace fees | 5% of job value | 95% |
| Enterprise SaaS | $99-$5k+/mo | 80% |
| Managed compute | $29-$299/mo per worker | 50% |
| Payment processing | 1% of Lightning volume | 70% |

children: Unit economics are anchored by receipts + verification: pay-after-verify for objective jobs.
Unit economics (illustrative)
Receipt-backed, usage-based pricing with Lightning settlement.

props.code:
Per Job (1,000 sats / ~$0.40)
  - Platform fee (5%): 50 sats
  - Lightning routing: ~1 sat
  - Provider receives: 949 sats
  - Platform gross margin: ~98%

Revenue sharing (example)
  - Agent creator: 40%
  - Compute provider: 20%
  - Model/data provider: 10%
  - Referrer: 5%
  - Platform: 25%

children: Micropayments make pay-per-inference viable. Receipts + verification make pay-after-verify enforceable.
How enterprises buy OpenAgents
Land with Engineering, expand across departments under one contract.
Who buys
VP Engineering / Platform: coding + DevOps agents
Head of Support: support agents
Revenue leaders: sales + marketing agents
CTO/AI office: marketplace + policy standardization
What they buy
Catalog of vetted agents for workflows (security scans, code review, triage, research)
Enterprise subscription: SSO, audit logs, policy, internal marketplace controls
Usage-based pricing: jobs + managed compute
Enterprise revenue per logo (illustrative)
Land with Engineering, expand across teams and departments.

props.code:
**Stage 1 - Team pilot (~$50K-$150K ACV)**
- 50-100 engineers on coding agents (Code Fixer, Security Scan, test generation)
- Prove measurable workflow value (typechecks, PR review, security scans)

**Stage 2 - Multi-team rollout (~$250K-$500K ACV)**
- Add Support + Sales agents (ticket triage, sales intel, content)
- One enterprise subscription with SSO, policy, audit, internal marketplace controls

**Stage 3 - Standardized marketplace ($1M+ ACV potential)**
- OpenAgents becomes the approved agent marketplace across the company
- Revenue mix: platform fee (SaaS) + committed job volume + managed compute

Community: 198+ video episodes building in public.

children: Why we win
Open protocols + observable execution + native payments.

props.code:
| Factor | OpenAgents | GPT Store | LangSmith |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Multi-model | Any model | OpenAI only | Yes |
| Open protocols | Nostr/Lightning | No | No |
| Built-in payments | Lightning | No | No |
| Creator revenue share | Transparent | Unclear | No |
| Decentralized | Yes | No | No |
| Enterprise compliance | Yes | Partial | Yes |

children: Go-to-market: developers first, then enterprises
Wedge with coding agents, then standardize the marketplace for the whole company.

props.code:
**Phase 1 - Developers (Year 1)**
- Wedge: coding agents running in repos (Code Fixer, Security Scan, test generation)
- Channels: technical content, OSS agents, community
- Metrics: MAU, jobs run, agent retention

**Phase 2 - Enterprise (Year 2)**
- Lock-in: dashboard, policy, compliance, auditability across teams
- Land: one department on annual contract + committed job volume
- Expand: add agents + teams under the same contract

**Phase 3 - Broad adoption (Year 3+)**
- Templates, vertical bundles, self-serve plans
- Metrics: total users, GMV, revenue

The only place you can hire the best agents, powered by open protocols and protocol-native payments.
